Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that voting on Sunday is wrong because it goes against the Sabbath and is dedicated to God. This assumption may be problematic as it assumes a specific religious belief and does not take into account the diversity of religious beliefs and practices.
Lack enough support: The claim does not provide sufficient evidence or support to justify the assertion that voting on Sunday is wrong. It relies on the opinion of Sen. Cindy Hyde-Smith without presenting any additional evidence or arguments.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that Sen. Cindy Hyde-Smith represents Mississippi, not Georgia, as mentioned in the expert's verdict. This contradiction undermines the credibility of the claim.
Exaggerate: The claim may be seen as an exaggeration as it presents the opinion of one senator as a general statement about the wrongness of voting on Sunday. It does not acknowledge that there may be differing opinions on this matter.
Understate: There is no evidence of understatement in the claim.
